11.73.text: (Tim Hosking) The Macquarie Marshes Wetlands system is

14.46.text: a huge water dependent complex environment.

17.37.text: It’s something that at an international, national and state

20.81.text: and local level we’ve chosen to support.

23.94.text: (Debbie Love) Very significant because of its size and its location

28.53.text: out in semi-arid Australia. And it’s really important

34.56.text: the whole of the south east of Australia.

37.73.text: (Peter McLellan) I remember the marshes pre-Burrendong,

40.06.text: very lucky to be in part of that and be able to remember it

44.11.text: because it was a very significant place.

48.06.text: We’d measured the reeds in one particular place,

51.27.text: we were doing a fence line and we though oh gee

53.81.text: they’re reaching high there and we measured them and they were 18 feet.

56.63.text: (Garry Hall) My father came here in 1960 and my great-grandfather bought

60.64.text: the place in 1934 so our family has had

62.96.text: a long association with the marshes.

64.81.text: Growing up here as a kid in my memory of it it was pretty healthy.

71.90.text: Yeah birds everywhere, like now what

74.44.text: we call endangered I can clearly remember my

78.49.text: father scaring us as kids with the Brown Bittern,

82.58.text: Australasian Bittern that we’d hear booming during the summer

85.77.text: time and that was, he told us it was a bunyip

90.19.text: and we believed him. So Ibis colonies in the big

93.78.text: floods, yeah our family’s always had an interest in

97.14.text: nature and birds. As kids we were taught the link

102.74.text: between a healthy environment, a healthy landscape

105.02.text: and healthy production for our business.

110.68.text: (Debbie Love) The late 60’s government decided as

114.27.text: they had in many parts of the state to build a large

117.34.text: dam to secure water supplies for a growing population.

121.08.text: And one of the effects of that was that it

123.62.text: disrupted the flow of water into the marshes.

126.90.text: And that has had and continues to have ongoing effect

130.14.text: on the ecosystem by changing how much water arrives

134.30.text: here and the patterns with which it arrives here.

137.85.text: So the system is really still adjusting to that

140.90.text: quite significant change in the water supply.

145.31.text: (Sam Davis) Macquarie Marshes provides a mosaic

148.19.text: of really, really vital and important habitats

150.56.text: and we’re increasing our understanding on how

153.60.text: native fish use these mosaics of habitats.

157.28.text: So they use these areas for breeding, for feeding,

160.44.text: a conduit for travel, finding mates.

163.56.text: (Tim Hosking) The Macquarie- Cudgegong Environmental Flows

165.87.text: Reference Group was first formed officially in 2004.

169.65.text: Although it arose from other committees before that

172.81.text: where for a long period New South Wales Office of

175.79.text: Environment and Heritage or its predecessors liked to

178.30.text: get local input into environmental water decisions.

181.05.text: (Ian Rogan) The challenge for the Macquarie-Cudgegong Environmental

183.95.text: Flows Reference Group is to provide I think balanced

187.05.text: advice on the management of environmental water to achieve

191.55.text: a range of outcomes. Primarily of course good

194.67.text: environmental outcomes for the Macquarie Marshes

197.02.text: and the whole of the Macquarie-Cudgegong river system.

200.12.text: But given the competing interests for water in this valley

205.31.text: and every other valley we need to take into account social

209.47.text: and economic impacts as well as environmental benefits

212.46.text: of managing our environmental water and it’s in my view

216.65.text: really important that there is a diverse group of

220.19.text: people with a range of interests around the table

222.58.text: to provide advice on the best way to manage environmental water.

230.49.text: (Jane Judd) The outcomes thatwe’re really trying to maintain are the

234.28.text: core values of the Macquarie Marshes. They were much more extensive in the

240.09.text: past, they’re going to be important in the future, wetlands have disappeared

243.85.text: throughout huge areas of the world.

247.40.text: (Danielle Flakelar) We get to be engaged in water management

251.88.text: issues, be part of decision making and planning,

255.31.text: particularly about when water’s going to be

258.33.text: released, what we’re trying to achieve out of that

260.76.text: water, where it will be best utilised in that

264.66.text: particular season given the rains, was there rains

268.17.text: there before, was there water sent previously

271.81.text: and will ours enhance the water flow that had flown before it.

277.89.text: in the Macquarie goes back about 30 years.

279.97.text: And it was long recognised even as the dam

282.66.text: was being built that the changes that would happen

285.51.text: would have an effect on the marshes.

287.53.text: So from the early 80’s there’s been an environmental

291.08.text: water allowance for the Macquarie Marshes and over

295.89.text: time that’s grown as we’ve come to understand more

298.63.text: and more about the water requirements of the system.

301.27.text: (Tim Hosking) Part of achieving a maximum benefit from the water

303.97.text: is taking stock of the antecedent conditions that exist

308.15.text: before we send the water down and then making a plan

312.42.text: that really does respond to the environment’s needs in

315.21.text: that particular year but also over time, looking

318.71.text: back three to five years and forwards.

324.87.text: (Ian Rogan) The community expects that that large

327.34.text: volume of environmental water entitlement is

330.36.text: efficiently managed. Some years there’ll be lots

333.56.text: of environmental water available to use, other

336.43.text: years such as this much less. We need to as close

340.90.text: as possible I think replicate what would have

343.90.text: achieved in a naturally unregulated system but then again we need to

348.20.text: take into account that in a regulated river system

350.57.text: such as this there are many other competing uses

353.91.text: for water and we need to demonstrate efficiency

356.84.text: in the use of environmental water.

358.58.text: (Debbie Love) Often people think that the environment

360.95.text: gets more water or is treated differently to other water

365.41.text: uses but that’s not the case, we’re all subject to the same rules.

371.78.text: (Ken Harris) It’s well known that these

373.42.text: wetlands exist in a drying/wetting cycle over a

377.85.text: long period of time. They do go through prolonged

379.90.text: periods of dry before they have their big boom years.

382.72.text: But of course it’s important given the

385.19.text: natural wetting regime has been changed to have

388.18.text: events like the one we’re seeing at the moment

390.02.text: to keep them spinning along between their big boom years.

395.46.text: (Debbie Love) We know we can’t return

397.67.text: the marshes to what they were before Burrendong

400.44.text: Dam was built but we hope to maintain some of

404.28.text: the functions and values that the wetlands have.

407.88.text: (Jane Judd) The wetlands are an important

412.45.text: They are an essential part of the ecosystem.

417.31.text: (Garry Hall) I’m still optimistic that things will look

419.99.text: better in 10/20/50 years than they do now.
